text: [2/2/17] Draught at City Tap House in Boston. Black. Huge vegetal coffee aroma. Sweet flavor, roast, vegetal coffee, some chocolate, alcohol. Medium-bodied.

500 ml bottle poured into a snifter. The beer is a near black with a khaki head of foam. The aroma has roasty coffee notes and big vanilla bean. Bitter and roasty taste. Thick mouthfeel, almost chewy. Moderate carbonation. Overall very good beer, but the coffee has fallen off a little bit.
500 ml. bottle. Pours black with an average tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, vanilla, and bourbon. Taste is coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, and roasted malt. Nice.

Tap at the source. Pours black, tan head. Aroma is sort of cold roasted coffee, chocolate, vanilla, smoke. Not much bourbon. But still good. Sort of a sweet fruit note, almost like jam but smokey. Flavor is smokey, roasted malt, coffee. Not much bourbon. Still very enjoyable.

Bottle from March 15. Coffee seems to have faded quite a bit. Poured a dark brown color with thin sudsy tan head. Aroma of oak, vanilla, chocolate, and coffee. Flavor was chocolate up front, coffee was there, but not overly present, vanilla, hints of oak and spirits. Full body, creamy texture, average carbonation, and a slight alcohol burn to finish.

Pours a dark dark brown with a beige rim that leaves low lacing. Nose is a nice mix of coffee and chocolate. Taste is of chocolate and coffee and while pretty sweet, not too sweet. Full body, medium carbonation and a rich/dense mouthfeel. Alcohol is expertly hidden. Really nice!

Bottle 500ml.
Pours black with low beige head. Some lacing. Aroma is of coffee, roasted malt, vanilla. Chocolate. Taste is of coffee, roasted malt, sugar, chocolate, alcohol. Palate: Full bodied. Soft-medium carbonation. Sticky on the lips. Overall: Quite nice. Heavy, sweet. Nice malt / coffee features.

Bottle (500 ml) shared at tasting. Dark reddish mahogany-brown with a small beige head leaving little lacing. Aroma is of coffee, strong caramel malts, roasted malts, bourbon, vanilla, vegetal notes but not in a bad way as well as a bit of a nutty presence. Taste isnt too sweet even though theres a good malt depth as well as a good amount of caramel/molasses and bourbon. Coffee is there and less vegetal than nose, theres interesting earthy/mineral notes and chocolatey notes. Medium to full body. Moderate carbonation. Mildly liquorous mouthfeel. Nice alcohol warmth. Well balanced. Good BBA Coffee Porter.

pours unclear very dark brown, bordeaux tint, with a small reviving light beige cap offering some retention and lacing. dense roasted caramel maltiness, tons of roasted avelines, smooth yet strong coffee - city roast; tasty bourbon - never overwhelming, salty caramel, minerals. low carbonation, full body; warming, smooth and drying spicy-coffee finish. very complex maltiness - burnt caramel and chocolate topped with maple bourbon solids/pieces. excellent!
Bottle pours out black topped with a tan head. nose is lots of coffee heavy roast malts bourbon barrel maple syrup. Taste is coffee heavy bourbon barrel vanilla brown sugar.
Bottle share at the WWWW beer tasting at iphonephans. Deep brown with small tan head. Roast coffee and chocolate. Rich and good.

Bottle from the brewery thanks to Dan. Pours black with a thick two finger of dark tan head. Aromas of robust coffee, dark malts, oak, chocolate, and hints of coconut. Taste of dark chocolate, ash, burnt espresso, burnt sugar, and dry oak. Solid

Pours out opaque black with a tan head that quickly fades. Aroma is liquor, chocolate and roasted malt. Pleasant to drink, lots of oak without overwhelming the coffee or the sweet and heavy base beer. Thick and chewy mouthfeel as expected. 2015 bottle with about 9 months of aging.
Bottle, pours black with small beige head. Aromas and flavor are roasted malt, coffee bean, oak, light chocolate, and some caramel booze. Body is light to medium for a 10 percent. Nice stuff.

Bottle shared by a chill bro in a location remote of my dining room. 
Pours a very dark brown with a small head. 

The aroma is plenty coffee forward with a pleasantly light handed bourbon character, but certainly vanilla forward, roasty... rich... inviting & cool. 

The flavor has a great bitter chocolate thing happening, its got a great coffee character & has some nice vanilla. The barrel character is well employed but light enough to be more complimentary than prominent. The beer is lightly sweet, a little peppery and pretty dang rich

Coffee and caramel aroma, dark brown color with brown foam, coffee, chocolate, toffee flavor. Boozy finish

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle to glass. Deep brown to black in color with a creamy tan head. Aroma has a solid coffee presence with a nice roasty malty backbone, touch of barrel. Boozy, slight barrel in the flavor. Solid.

[ Bottle ][ 1oz ][ @tasting ][ $0 ][ Shot glass ][ 08.15.15 ]sepia with small bubbled cream head. Lightly green coffee nose alongside chocolate, low roast. Sweet front palate, low roast and no hops, some sweeter coffee mid that again couples with chocolate, slick with low carbonation, stinging under-attenuation showing by end.

Bottle from a trade. A really inviting nose of vanilla and coffee and booze. Taste is lightly bitter chocolate with a nice roasty note. Really dang smooth and nice. No signs of alcohol. Just smooth and yum.
Poured from bottle cola black with a lacey coca head. Aromas of coffee chocolate roasted malt and vanilla. Taste follows aroma with a balanced bourbon note. Quite a nice brew.
16.9 oz bottle - thanks Kirk! Deep brown hue. Lightly sweetened coffee aroma. Dryish barrel character, plenty of coffee and chocolate malts.

Half liter bottle thanks to secret Santa crajun, shared at the WWWW Mid Atlantic Summer Beer Tasting. Clear dark brown, thin head. Aroma of roasted malts, bourbon, coffee, chocolate, vanilla. The taste is chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, oak, coffee. Medium bodied, low carbonation, mildly boozy.
Roast and light coffee with milk chocolate. Black with mocha head. Big caramel. Slightly syrupy. Bittersweet. Bottle.
From a 50 cl bottle at the WWWW RB tasting it is a dark brown color with an ecru head. The aroma is mocha and the taste is bourbon and coffee and the finish is milk chocolate.

Bottle at the RateBeer WWWW Tasting shared by Drake, thanks! Dark brownish black with light tan head. Aromas of caramel, coffee, dark fruit, caramel. Tastes of coffee, dark chocolate, roast, dark fruit. Medium body with a dry finish.
From a 50 cl bottle at the WWWW RB tasting. Pours a murky dark cola with an ecru head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Flavors of chocolate.
Bottle. Clear maroon color. Aroma of toasted brownies dipped in coffee. Taste is roasty coffee grounds and cocoa. Very nice.
Dark pour, 1 finger of head. Coffee grounds and whiskey in the aroma and taste, hints of vanilla. Slight also l warming. Medium body.
Tap at Pony Bar. Chocolatey smooth porter. Cream caramel and raisina. Carbonic acid and licorice. Finished with some roasted coffee

Bottle shared at Kickback thanks to Ryan. Pours a dark brown with no head. Aroma is of chocolate fudge and a slight bit of stale coffee. Slight vanilla. Taste is sweet with that lager yeast grape skin thing. I dont like that much. Underwhelmed.
Thanks J!! The smell is coffee grounds, chocolate, dark fruit licorice. The taste is as it smells with alcohol detected. The body is full with fine carbonation.
Many thanks to Rian for sharing! Malty-smooth, a bit too alcoholic, smooth. Coffee, fresh, not too balanced in my eyes. Fresh, coffee, smooth chocolate, not too round, malty bitter aftertaste. Nice.
Scharfer Kaffeeantrunk, gut versteckte Alkoholnoten. Malzig süß, die Kaffeenoten werden geringer, dass Bier bleibt aber vollmundig. 10/9/11/12//11
Good improvement over the base BA Fram, with a nice spicy coffee note and beautiful aroma. Alcohol was harsh up front, but mellowed as it warmed. Overall a nice brew.
Bottle pour is black, aroma is roast, green vegetable, spicy coffee, taste is big coffee roast with light bourbon finish
Bottle split with the wife. Pours dark with a tan head that leaves a nice oil slick cap. Coffee is in upfront, light oak, smoke, cocoa. Medium body with a light booze burn.

Great Porter with a smooth feel with coffee and bourban taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle - Chocolate and nice rich coffee notes. Deep jet brown with a light beige head. Nice coffee, vanilla, chocolate and a long Roasty finish. Nice.

Bottle. Pours black with a dark brown head that dissipates to edges slowly. Aroma has a good pint of coffee with musty dark grains and a touch of roasted malt. Flavor has roasted malts and coffee with an earthy dark grain note.
Dark brown pour with a slight tan head. Nose is coffee forward. Balanced, some barrel character with a nice hint of coffee, not overwhelming at all. Really nice.

Aroma is coffee, earthy, vanilla, bourbon. Taste is like aroma. Lovely body. Good dessert beer. Not over the top. I think I prefer the regular one over this one. The regular is less sweet. Nonetheless, lovely beer.

quite dense beige head fades quite fast. coffee coloured. aroma is coffee, earthy, vanilla, bit boozy. taste like aroma, roasted malts, liquorice, ash, some alcoholsweetness with a fair bitter aftertaste. quite dense mouthfeel, medium carbonation. very nice, although i like their regular baltic porter just a bit more.bottle 50cl

Bottle and served in tulip: The initial pour was very pretty but alas the head died too quickly. The nose has lots of liquorice, some vanilla, oak, smoke and faint coffee. The java character is more present on the palate but the malt tones are still dominate and the barrel notes add a layer of complexity but this screams for a bit more noble hop bitterness. Some dark chocolate and still more anise tones. Smooth and sticky but not overly heavy mouthfeel, for a coffee imbued and barrel aged beer it is damn solid palate. Overall, I really like parts of this brew but am left wanting sharper bitters and more lasting carbonation. Good to try once... Liked the Vanilla Bean version more.

From notes. Finally found the long-lost notebook from the 4 Elf Party at Dark Horse on December 13! So, thats where this was found. Shared by a passer-by for a chance to hang around the campfire wed built. The pour is a really dark black with a small white head. I was expecting a darker head for a Baltic, but it let me down a touch. The aroma has a lot of alcohol up front. Behind that lies the coffee, lots of licorice, some hints of vanilla and toffee. The flavor is very similar. There is a bit more of a roasted malt in the flavor than the nose led on. The back end tails off into something much more bitter. Lots of coffee ad dark chocolate. The mouth feel is oily, yet slick. The carbonation is soft, but it disappears quickly. The aftertaste is lingeringly bitter and roasty. Nice Baltic Porter
500ml bottle pours a black color without much head. Nice coffee flavor that balances well against the barrel and malt flavors. Some sweetness balances the coffee nicely too.

Bottle at De Garde. Pours a pitch black color with a small white head. A big coffee and huge smoky nose, roast. The flavor is super sweet roast, licorice, smoke, vanilla. A slick palate. Quite good. Comes in big and yet is drinkable.

Bottled March 2013. Poured 12/25/14. Opaque brown-black with a thing light-brown-beige head. Aroma is alcohol, bourbon, vanilla, banana, sweet, caramel, toffee, roast malts, coffee. Taste is bourbon, vanilla, leather, nutty, banana, slightly floral, earth, roast malt, coffee, alcohol; finish is bitter roast malt, dark chocolate. Oily laces. Low carbonation. Oily but full mouthfeel. Certainly, with the age this bottle has, the coffee has fallen off. Still, quite an excellent example of the style and lagers in general. Nice.

Un corps voluptueux et soyeux supporte les petits fruits sucrés de la levure lager et de léventail de céréales. Le café se présente sous forme de mocha et sa torréfaction est minime. La plus ronde est délicate de la série jusquà maintenant.

A - pours an almost opaque cola brown with no head. Bvwry thin tan ring of bubbles. S - nose is a bit sweeter than the base with a toasted simple sugar, caramel, and coffee. The barrel character seems muted by the coffee addition. It's a combo between the grainy notes of the base with the sweet barrel character, with coffee. Sharp boozy end. M - full bodied. Sharp booze up front to a malty palate with coffee bitters end. T - the taste is all the characters of the base and the barrel version with a nice coffee addition. Toasted caramel, tobacco, leather, sweet barrel character and coffee. O - a nice variant. The coffee tones down the barrel character. 3.8

Bottle that I took to RBSDG at the Dad Pad. Pours a deep black with a thin beige head. Roast and cofee, chocolate, warming vanilla tones. Cocoa, warm coffee, no pepper notes which is nice. Supremely smooth, no alcohol showing up. Long roast and coffee, hints of spicy chocolate. Lovely.
Dark brown. Fresh coffee and cocoa, light-medium sticky mouthfeel. Very good.
Bottle. Lighter and smoother than the original with light coffee on the finish. Excellent mouthfeel. Light but rich. Excellent.
Bottle. Identical to the base beer but with some coffee grinds in the taste. Not bad.

Pours thick murky brown, viscous with a beige head. The aroma and flavor both bring sweet coffee slowly and then strong on the senses. This is the third time I have had it and the coffee is much sweet and less roasted than the past, but so delicious and smooth. There are spicy sweet almost rum like booze notes that please the palate.

Bottle at RBSDADG 2014 courtesy of Jay, I believe. Pours a rich blackish brown body with thin brown lacing. Aroma is rich, luscious coffee and sweet chocolate. Light brownie character on the nose. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy - with muted roasty notes and lots of coffee and chocolate. I preferred the vanilla-treated version to this, but still a knockout porter.

I brought the whole 2012 set to our monthly tasting.


A - Pours pitch black with a nice one finger tall tan head, slowly dissipating down to a light film, leaving small streaks of lace down the sides of the glass.


S - Smells of strong coffee, vanilla, bourbon, oak, coconut, chocolate and smokey dark malt. The coffee is quite strong while still being balanced with the other aromas, very nice work.


T - Starts off with the strong fresh brewed coffee slowly being joined by some mild sweetness, - mainly the chocolate and vanilla - toasted coconut, smoked malt and warming woody bourbon. Finish is pretty roasty with some mild sweetness, lingering long after the finish. Not as well balanced as the nose but still really nice.


M - Heavy body with moderate carbonation. Smooth, roasty feel with some nice sweetness to even it all out. A bit of tannins and very light booze dry the palate at the end of each sip.


O - This was probably my favorite of the three, just barely beating out the vanilla. The coffee really accentuated the base flavors and yet it remained easy to consume. Glad I could try this one and share it with everyone.
Bottle. Pours deep brown with a beige head. Rich coffee and sweet malts, lighter roasted malty notes, caramel, and chocolate. Rich and delicious.

Bottle; Pour is murky brown, with a fine bubbled, modest khaki head into this glass. It retains on the average / below average side, with moderate spotting presence. The nose is cereal grain, brown sugar, chocolate morsel - this being my 3rd framinghammer ; its what I expected. The coffee addition really works here (far more so than the vanilla). The flavor profile is more chocolate morsel, light chocolate cake, moving to the cereal grain, mild astringent note, brown sugar sweetness, and then it hits the roasted coffee bean near the finish line. Yet another terrific rendition from Jacks!

Coffee, vanilla, booze, toast. Pours solid black with a quickly fading dark tan head. Medium bodied. Candy brown sugar sweet. Glassy smooth mouthfeel with just a little edge on the finish. Roasty, coffee, vanilla, toffee. Really outstanding.
Bottle shared by Jay at RBSDG. Pours dark brown. Nose/taste of fresh coffee, vanilla, light bourbon, touch of earthy malt and roast. Medium body. Smooth. No pepper from the coffee.

Bottle: Thanks, Alex. Absolutely black, no light at all with a frothy ecru film that perches nicely on top. Aroma of superbly roasted, oily coffee beans, charred dark malt, a hint of spicy wood, warming booze, & a little bit of sweet raisin entering towards the back-end. Smooth, roasted coffee flavor complete with some roasted malts & dark cocoa. Just a faint hint of creamy sweetness balances the roast nicely without overdoing it. Not as much barrel present on the palate, but the coffee aspect makes up for it. Lightly creamy body. A delicious porter with a lovely coffee & chocolate, lingering finish.

Bottle at Jacks a Slapper tasting, thanks to LKS, 12/05/14.
Cola black with a moderate tan covering that clears to a swirl.
Nose carries a big coffee load, dark chocolate, spice, light roastings.
Taste comprises much the same, coffee less intense than on the nose, coffee grinds well evident, roast malt, light vanilla, dark chocolate.
Medium + bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Solid coffee fuelled porter.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle thanks to tectactoe for sharing. Almost black pour with a small foamy ring of head. Aroma is packed with medium roasted coffee, chocolate fudget, chocolate cake, and oak. Tastes like fresh roasted coffee and chocolate cake. Some light sweetness up front and then the bitter coffee lingers in the finish. Love these framinghammer beers.

Courtesy of tectactoe
Bottle: The aroma consists of moderate roasted coffee/espresso, chocolate, black licorice, and faint bourbon. It pours a dark brown with some faint orange highlights. It has a one finger beige head that fades to a thin film outlined by a thicker ring. There is some spotty lacing left on the sides of the glass. The flavor starts with chocolate, camel, and a hint of molasses. The finish has moderate roasted coffee, light black licorice, and a hint of bourbon. It medium-full bodied with mild carbonation and a somewhat soft mouthfeel.

Bottle shared by Brandon, thanks man! Pour is a standard dark brown with a small brown head. Aroma is a little off. Certainly roasted malt and coffee dominate but notes of pumpkin and some vegetal notes creep in too. Also light vanilla and light alcohol. Flavor is also notable for vegetal notes with roasted malt dominating. Coffee comes in later with some faint bourbon notes. Just a little off to me.

This was my favorite of the Framinghammers. Pours a dark brown, tan head, nice aromas of roasted malts and coffee...a slight booze. Taste is nicely balanced with loads of coffee, light bitter hops, then some caramel/toffee/butterscotch undertones before a slightly bitter and mildly boozy finish. Great stuff!

Bottle thanks to Russell. Pours a dark brown with small beige head. The aroma is strong roast, coffee bean, pine. Medium mouthfeel with sweet roast, coffee bean, caramel, with light bitterness. Very good.

A very special beer. Be warned: it has a lot of alcohol and you can smell & taste the bourbon. But that's what makes it special. It is bold and dark with a very nice finish on the palate. Had it on tap at a BBQ battle--delicious with pulled pork and ribs!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
draft at Tap & Mallet, black pour, medium bodied, no head. coffee flavor, roasted malts, touch of dark chocolate. pretty hefty at 10%. Impressive
Rich and creamy mouthfeel, roasted coffee and chocolate flavor. Roasted nuts aroma and coffee bean. Incredibly well balanced, onr of the best porters i have had

12th May 2014Tasting at Bruces pad. Thanks to Leighton. Almost opaque dark brown beer, bubbly pale tan head. Palate is airy and light. Little fine carbonation. Mild dark malts, nice touches of vanilla and chocolate. Little spice. The coffee is fairly mellow. Light finish with more alcohol spice.

Sampled this at Tap and Mallet total tap takeover. Dark mahogany with dark biege head. Lots of peat, oak, smooth and lots-O-alcohol. Full body, mild carbonation, more peat, quite dry finish. Same as Barrel aged but with coffee added.

Bottle shared by b3shine. Poured a black color with an average brown head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Good roasted coffee and chocolate malt aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy sweet roasted coffee and malt flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Very good coffee porter.
Bottle @ Bruces. deep brown with a tiny head. Nose is strong coffee and cocoa, Nutella. taste is cocoa, bear claw, caramel, slight acidity. Medium dy. oily. Nice.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2014 Bottle, big thanks to Leighton . It pours near black with a thin beige head. The nose is rich, sweet, coffee, brown sugar, treacle, candy and more milky candy. The taste is bitter-sweet, toasty, candy, roast, milk, candy, coffee frappe, rocky road and sugar with a dry, sweet finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. A bit sweet and thin for my liking. A bit more  body and this could have been a lot better.

Bottle shared in London - picked up from the brewery. Pours deep brown, clear, with a creamy beige head. The nose has a bit of espresso, dark bread, cocoa, slight toasted wood. Medium sweet flavor with rich cafe con leche, a bit of espresso, milk chocolate, raisins. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. Finishes sweet with more rich coffee, milk chocolate, rich bread, mild alcohol boost. Definitely a solid coffee/ cocoa beer.

500 ml bottle shared by b3shine. Pours dark cola brown in color with a small beige head. The aroma and flavor have rich roasted malts, more coffee than the regular BA version, chocolate, bourbon, wood, light vanilla and earth. Medium-bodied, lasting finish. Very good, but not blown away.

500ml bottle, thanks to b3shine for sharing. Drank right after standard BA framingham. Dark brown color. Slight redness to it. Kind of clear around the edges. Thin ring of khaki head. Some bubbles in the head. Awesome big coffee up front in the nose. Bigger bitter taste than the standard BA. Mild sweet. Light bit of alcohol. Bigger body, a good chewiness to the texture. Some dark chocolate. Lightly soft, lighter carbonation. More dry finish. Very nice complex flavorful lager. More of a spicy light sweet bite in the finish than the standard BA seemed to have, but I love that coffee aspect.

Bottle to snifter (shared with the group). Looks good; a translucent dark brown with beige head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells good too; dark malt, oak and loads of coffee. Tastes like it smells, but not quite as rich. Good on the palate. Nice stuff.

Bottle... Pitch black pour with a small, creamy, khaki head and several fat bubbles. The bouquet delivers big-time mocha, toasted oak, tree nuts and vanilla. Medium to full-bodied with tingly carbonation. The flavor is an acrid, roasty blend of charcoal, red-hot bourbon and dark-roast mocha. Finishes acrid and boozy. Bottle courtesy of landhoney!

50cl bottle sampled side by side with the Vanilla version. Pours an oily, opaque black with some cloudy, white head. Nose has a lot of coffee, bright coffee grounds, nutty, caramel, mild licorice. Flavor is the same, coffee, caramel, licorice, a fair amount of smoke.

Bottle. Brown-black pour with a nice off-white head. Aroma is deep espresso and milk chocolate. I also find layers of butter and cream that makes it exquisite. Taste is roasted malts, coffee and cream. So rich without being cloying and overly sweet, oats adds a nice creamy touch. Extremely well balanced imperial stout. The most intense (and best) oat stout Ive had.

At Jacobs with group. Pour is black with a circle of white head. Aroma is pungent lightly roasted malt, smooth vanilla marshmallow notes. Taste is drinkable medium body roasted malt. Incredibly smooth, would pound all day. Could drink on a hot day, easy. Interesting for a drinkable beer.
Nice dark brown pour, very small head. Flavor is loaded with coffee, light hints of ash, barrel, toasted oak, bourbon, roast and a dry bitter finish.

Bottle from trade. Pours milky black with nice tall tan head. Coffee aroma is great, some nutmeg and vanilla as well. Taste is big punch of coffee, some vanilla notes. Quite sweet. The alcohol is well hidden here. Great porter.

Bottle with thanks to Reynolds314! Pours opaque black with a nice small creamy tan head that dissipates slowly and laces well. Aroma is not overpowering, notes of coffee, roasted malts, a bit of ashtray, some bourbon. Flavor is boozier than the nose - bourbon prominent, some oak, nice chocolate and roasty coffee notes as well. Light to medium sweetness, medium bitterness and some acidity from the coffee as well the time in wood. Full, creamy body. A bit hot due to ABV. Gets a bit bitter with time as you drink it.

From the bottle at the EBF Saturday
Nice coffee and thick chocolate aged in wood.Nice beer

Fresh bottle, drunk 3/9/14Small tan head diminishes fairly rapidly, leaving a dark brown body, with deep garnet highlights.Thankfully far less bourbon in the nose than the Vanilla version showed. Still there, of course, but its not a mess of coconut and pineapple and actually allows the beer to break through. Raisins, black licorice and light chocolate with barrel notes providing vanilla, light buttercream and some sharper alcohol dryness. Probably the lightest thing in the nose is the coffee, which is limited to very light roast, dry, crunchy coffee grinds and more vanilla. No deep espresso or thick, juicy cold-pressed beans here.Light bourbon and rather dry, tannic wood notes lead the sweet caramel-vanilla maltiness while a touch of raisins and prunes give way to light coffee but no where near the amount of barrel character and vanilla that that version showed. Still, its fairly sweet, a little low on carbonation and somewhat simplistic.Slowly slogging my way through these massive Jacks Abby beers. This one is certainly better than the vanilla bottle I had and I fully expect the barrel-aged version to top that and the regular framinghammer to, in turn, top that. We shall see.

500ml bottle thanks to NHhophead! Pours dark almost opaque brown with 2 finger mocha head. Nose is rich earthy roasty coffee, cream, balanced fruity bourbon. Taste is creamy smooth coffee, cocoa, bakers chocolate, balanced bourbon undertones, dark fruits. Finish is bitter dusty roast coffee and cocoa, mocha. Fantastic.

Bottle at home with friends. Pour is deep brown with a frothy tan head and good lacing. Coffee, green pepper, roasty, light cocoa, caramel, pie crust, burnt toffee, and toast in the aroma. Taste is rich earthy coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla, bread, somewhat grassy, vanilla, pie crust, and marshmallows with a smooth roasted finish. Slick mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Really tasty stuff.

Pour out of 500 mL bottle, thanks Stephen! Dark black pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of dark chocolate, coffee, roast, hints of vanilla, nice espresso, very nice. Taste is a nice mix of dark coffee, espresso, vanilla, roast, hints of nice molasses, finishing fairly sweet, slightly bitter.

Bottle @ Steve_0s palace, courtesy of Stephen. Thanks! Pours a clear dark brown appearance with a thin brown head. A bit acidic, dark fruity, coffee, sort of boozy, a touch smoky aroma. Moderate bodied. Kind of chewy, chocolate / burnt malty, caramel, toffee flavor. Fine to drink but not mind blowing.

Bottle. Somewhat grainy flimsy body. Earthy milk dud roast. Muddled earthy grajny coffee. Light roasty bitterness. Touch bitter chocolate. Vanilla candy. Okay but far preferred unbarreled framjnghammer. Cleaner. Keep it simple.

Pours deep mahogany into a snifter. Mocha micro head with good retention recedes to hug rim. Chocolate and coffee aromas. Medium bodied with soy and coffee front to back. Lasting, dry and slightly sour licorice finish

2014 batch, 500 ml into a snifter. Pours a deep black body with two fingers of tan foam. Decent lacing. Aroma is light roasted coffee, chocolate, and some caramel malt. Almost fudgey. Taste is light coffee and chocolate washed away by bright chocolate and caramel malt. Some residual sugars and coffee bitterness/dryness on the finish but it drinks rather light given the high abv. Just a notion of oak and vanilla on the finish but this isnt very barrel heavy at all. Creamy medium bodied mouth feel. This is very drinkable and delicious. Of course its easy to draw parallells to a stout so if youre expecting a BCBCS then youll be let down. This is lighter and creamier and a really fantastic beer.

Dark brown, moderate beige head. Sticky caramel, coffee roast, milk chocolate, creme, light bourbon, traces of vanilla. Bittersweet rounded out with an unexpected wood flavor. A little more than medium-bodied but not by much. Finishes on a somewhat herbal note with a little booziness.

Draft at the source. Pours black coffe brown with a beige head that fades to a thin coating and rims the glass. Aroma is coffee, vanilla, caramel malt. Less sweet than the Vanilla, the coffee is nice, giving this more balance. Undertone is still caramel, fig, soy, but the sweetness is balanced by a nice moderate coffee bitterness.

500ml bottle in a teku. Pours black with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, some chocolate, some bourbon and oak, some dough, and hints of vanilla. Flavor the same with a nice blend of the coffee, oak, and dark malts. Smooth texture. A good beer.

Slightly better then the vanilla but both are great. The coffee is roasty and very nice without being overpowering to the rest of the beer. The bourbon provides vanilla light boozyness and an oaky spicy back end. Great beer.
Bottle, the coffee is great in this one, good base beer and tasty. The bourbon takes a back step to the cofee

Pours a deep burnt umber with a finger of khaki foam. Lots of earthy coffee on the nose with traces of roasted chocolate malt and some bourbon too. The palate follows with alot more bourbon presence adding a nice heat and spice that balances the coffee nicely with a heavy chocolate roast backbone and a lingering bitter coffee finish. Really dialed in and well made beer !

Bottle, thanks Jao for an awesome night of ticks! Black-dark brown pour with off-white head. Aroma of cold pressed coffee, tons and tons of it, light roasty notes, a bit vegetal (like Kopi or cold brew). Taste is quite bitter, coffee, vanilla, very smooth flavor compared to the aroma that was a bit harsh. Palate is creamy, soft carbonation. Delicious.

500 ml bottle shared by bsuedekum- thanks again, Blake! Looks just like the other two variants- deep coffee brown, not opaque, smallish beige head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, earth, nuts, oak, and toasted sugar. The flavor is a lighter version of the same. Toasty finish. Light-medium bodied, with a sweet, dry, malty mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. A little thinner than Id want. About even with the Vanilla Bean version.
A little rough with the coffee but overall a ncie variant style of this beer.
Bottle. Chocolate, coffee, ash, malt and alcohol aroma. Black with small head. Sweet creamy mocha, wood, ash, malt and alcohol flavor. Very tasty.

(500ml bottle thanks Greg!) clear medium brown/amber, no real head. Nose of espresso, coffee with cream, raisins chocolate. Taste of rich coffee, lightly bitter like a good coffee, cream, fairly rich, nice beer. Raisiny finish.

Bottle courtesy of AirForceHops. Earthy coffee, boozy oak, vanilla, rich lactic chocolate, light ash aroma... and this crazy good cinnamon in the bottom notes. Black with a moderate creamy tan head. Creamy lactic Espresso... sort of like a good macchiato , bitter chocolate, boozy oak, and prune flavor with a light spicy bite in the finish. Medium bull body, soft carbonation. Thanks Chris, this was a nice one.
Bottle. Black pour with tan head. Coffee, dark malts, some other dark aromas. Dark flavor, roasted malt, some light coffee tones.

Thank you Chris for grabbing a bottle of each of these for me at the release. You rock man! 2 finger sticky, creamy leathery head. Pours almost black into the glass. Very much a porter appearance. Nose is creamy steamed milk latte with roasted cherries. Mind-blowingly big coffee taste. Like pouring myself an espresso, adding some milk and sugar and chugging. Great roasted notes finish, no burn, very drinkable. Loving the fact it tastes just like drinking a  carbonated espresso.

Sampled at the Game 7 Hawks-Wings tasting. Pours black in color with some brown hues around the edges. Nose is packed with delicious coffee. Much better than coffee smoke and dagger. Flavor is similarly coffee forward with some backing barrel character. Some drying oak and just a hung of bourbon. Light mouthfeel, good carbonation, some sweetness, and a moderate finish. Absolutely awesome, one of my favorite Jacks Abbys to date, probably my favorite non-hoppy lager.

I picked up all three barrel aged variations at Julios Liquors on 4 May 2013 for the special release. I am now comparing Side- by Side- by- Side. Insanely dark pour with thin tan head. Massive retention.  Wonderful aromas of bourbon, wet oak, chocolate and burnt malt. The coffee is a nice addition, yet it seems to dominate all the other flavors. The barrel notes and bourbon are almost not even noticeable.  Lingering espresso bean notes. Mouthfeel is on the medium side. Dont get me wrong, I love this brew and if you know somebody who went to Julios or the special brewery release, by all mean try this. It is a wonderful coffee brew that any coffee beer lover will enjoy. I like it, I just think the vanilla bean was a bit better. But Im splitting hairs here. Still a fine brew.
